Award.AwardTitle: Glycan Recognition and the Role of Innate Immunity in Cnidarian-dinoflagellate Symbioses
Award.AbstractNarration:
Coral reefs are profoundly important ecosystems that are threatened worldwide. Corals are animals that form the structural basis of these reefs, and contain microscopic algae inside their cells. This mutualistic partnership or symbiosis provides the foundation of the entire diverse coral reef ecosystem. While a great deal of attention has been focused on the environmental threats to corals and how and if corals will survive climate change, there remains only a partial understanding of the microscale cellular and molecular mechanisms that underpin the coral-algal symbiosis. Insight into regulation of this symbiosis will provide a stronger foundation for studies of the impact of ocean warming, acidification and other anthropogenic stressors on coral health. This project will bring together a coral biologist , a chemist, and a cancer cell biologist, to examine the intricate molecular and cellular conversations that the partners of the symbiosis engage in to initiate and maintain the symbiosis. The project will also examine how these conversations go awry and lead to symbiosis dysfunction and breakdown during the phenomenon of coral bleaching, a stress response to elevated temperature that results in coral death and reef degradation. In addition to studying corals in the field, this project will also study sea anemones which are an excellent proxy for corals, many of which are endangered and are difficult to culture in a laboratory setting. This project will contribute to the training of scientists and expose school-aged children to coral reef and symbiosis science.

Many cnidarians, including corals and anemones, engage in symbioses with photosynthetic dinoflagellates (Symbiodinium spp.), and together they form the trophic and structural foundation of the coral reef ecosystem. Despite the importance of corals to coral reefs and the threatened state of coral reef health in an era of dramatic climate change, the basic cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the initiation, establishment and breakdown of the partnership are only partially understood. This project will examine inter-partner signaling and host cell immune response during onset and breakdown of cnidarian-dinoflagellate symbioses. Experiments will be conducted in two model systems, the anemone Aiptasia sp.-Symbiodinium B1 and larvae of the coral Fungia scutaria-Symbiodinium C1f. The team proposes the following Specific Aims: Aim 1: Characterize glycan recognition between host and invading Symbiodinium by glycan profiling and glycome manipulation of the algae, and host receptor pull-down approaches. Aim 2: Compare structural dynamics of phagocytosis and intracellular signaling when hosts are challenged with Symbiodinium by analyzing phagocytic profiles, phagosomal markers, NF-kB activation and the signaling sphingosine rheostat in hosts challenged with different symbiont types and other particles. Aim 3: Examine disruptions and changes in phagosomal dynamics and cell signaling in partnerships subjected to elevated temperature that leads to bleaching by measuring changes in phagosomal maturation, activation of NF-kB and sphingolipid signaling in host tissues after an elevated temperature stress.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The symbiosis between corals and algae forms the trophic and structural foundation of coral reef ecosystems.  The single-celled algae that reside inside of coral cells provide food in the form of glucose to the host coral in return for a high light environment, shelter and fertilizer.  Coral reef ecosystems are threatened with almost complete destruction by the end of the century due to climate change.  Global warming causes the symbiosis to move toward dysbiosis where that algae are released from the coral host, causing a phenomenon called coral bleaching.  Bleached corals die and which in turn causes destruction of the entire reef ecosystem.

Despite the fundamental importance of corals to coral reef ecosystems, we are still just discovering the cellular and molecular mechanisms that underpin the cnidarian-algal symbiosis.  This award examined the regulation of these symbioses.  The work addressed such questions as: how does the partnership form with each host generation?  How does the host regulate the growth of its symbionts? What cellular signals cause the breakdown of the partnership that causes bleaching?

Corals are difficult to study in the laboratory because they grow very slowly, require very specific culturing conditions and are off-limits for collecting due to their endangered status.  This team of investigators therefore focused its efforts on a symbiotic sea anemone Exaiptasia pallida (Aiptasia) that harbors the same type of algae as do corals and which grows very well in the laboratory.  It is an excellent model system for the study of coral symbiosis.

Aim 1 of the work sought to examine the role of host-symbiont lock and key recognition mechanisms in the onset of symbiosis.  Host animals contain the equivalent of chemical locks, or receptor molecules on their surfaces that require the binding of a specific signaling chemical or key in order for the partnership to establish.  This mechanism of specificity results in a host species being able to choose the correct algal type out of a large variety that might be in the water column.  For this award, the interaction between host lectins (locks) and symbiont glycans (keys) was examined in detail.  The structure of glycans was described across several species of algae and then the glycan structures were chemically altered using pharmacological agents.  These alterd algae were then added to hosts and measured for their ability to start a symbiosis.  These studies have provided detailed information about host-symbiont recognition during onset of symbiosis.

Aim 2 examined a variety of pathways related to the host animal immune system which is responsible for recognizing different algal types as friend or foe.  One of the main outcomes of this aim was describing a molecule called NFkappaB which serves as a master gatekeeper for the host immune system.  When it is turned on, it causes cells to launch an immune response against invaders.  The structure of this gatekeeper molecule in cnidarians is very similar to that found in mammals and humans.  In experiments comparing symbiotic hosts to those that had been rendered algae-free, symbiotic animals were found to have less NFkappaB present, suggesting that being symbiotic with algae causes a tolerance response in the host that prevents it from mounting an immune response against algae.

Aim 3 studied the cellular mechanisms that underlie the bleaching response that occurs from an elevated temperature stress.  Among the several genes that were studied, on enzyme called NOX was featured.  NOX is an enzyme that forms on membranes and catalyzes the formation of poisonous reactive oxygen compounds.  It is part of an immune response.  After elevated temperature stress, it is hypothesized that NOX forms on the membrane that surrounds the intracellular algae and dumps poison compounds into the intracellular space around the algae, therefore stressing them and resulting in their destruction.  For this award, a specific label for NOX was synthesized and the behavior of NOX was observed during and after head stress.  The evidence for assembly on the membrane surround the algae could was not conclusive.

In summary, this award aimed to explore the cellular and molecular mechanisms driving healthy symbiosis and diseased dysbiosis in cnidarian-algal symbiosis.  Foundational understanding of these processes is essential as coral biologists race to develop a diverse array of solutions aimed at helping to save corals and coral reefs from destruction in this era of climate change.

Many scientists at all career stages participated in this research.  The Principal Investigators included an early-career investigator.  Work in all three groups was performed graduate students, undergraduates and a postdoctoral fellow as a part of their professional training.
